intro: Chelyocarpus wallisii, commonly known as the mangrove apple or sea apple, is a flowering plant native to coastal regions of Southeast Asia. It is a member of the Arecaceae family, commonly referred to as the palm family. The plant is characterized by its dense, fibrous roots that help stabilize coastal sediments and filter saltwater. Its fruit, which is edible, contains a single large seed enclosed in a fleshy, orange-colored pericarp. Chelyocarpus wallisii plays an important ecological role in mangrove ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various marine and terrestrial species.
